t: Ecclesiastes 1
The Vanity of Life
The*p words of the Preacher, the son of David, king in Jerusalem.
“Vanity*pn of vanities,” says the Preacher; “Vanity*ld of vanities, all is*i vanity.”
What*ln profit has a man from all his labor In*ld which he toils under the sun?
One*ild generation passes away, and another*i generation comes; But*ld the earth abides forever.
The*ld sun also rises, and the sun goes down, And*ld hastens to the place where it arose.
The*ld wind goes toward the south, And*ld turns around to the north; The*ld wind whirls about continually, And*ld comes again on its circuit.
All*ld the rivers run into the sea, Yet*ld the sea is*i not full; To*ld the place from which the rivers come, There*ld they return again.
All*ld things are*i full of labor; Man*ld cannot express it.*i The*ld eye is not satisfied with seeing, Nor*ld the ear filled with hearing.
That*ln which has been is*i what will be, That*ld which is*i done is what will be done, And*ld there*i is*i nothing new under the sun.
Is*ld there anything of which it may be said, “See,*ld this is*i new”? It*ld has already been in ancient times before us.
There*ild is*i no remembrance of former things,*i Nor*ld will there be any remembrance of things*i that are to come By*ld those*i who will come after.
The Grief of Wisdom
I,*p the Preacher, was king over Israel in Jerusalem.
And I set my heart to seek and search out by wisdom concerning all that is done under heaven; this burdensome task God has given to the sons of man, by which they may be exercised.
I have seen all the works that are done under the sun; and indeed, all is*i vanity and grasping for the wind.
What*ipn is*i crooked cannot be made straight, And*ld what is lacking cannot be numbered.
I*p communed with my heart, saying, “Look, I have attained greatness, and have gained more wisdom than all who were before me in Jerusalem. My heart has understood great wisdom and knowledge.”
And I set my heart to know wisdom and to know madness and folly. I perceived that this also is grasping for the wind.
For*pn in much wisdom is*i much grief, And*ld he who increases knowledge increases sorrow.
